questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Delirium tremens?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Acute delirium, also called delirium tremens, is commonly seen in alcohol withdrawal. Chronic delirium is not usually seen in alcohol withdrawal.
  • It develops around 3 days post-withdrawal and can last up to one week
  • The features of alcohol intoxication delirium include:
    • Delirium
    • Autonomic hyperactivity
    • Visual or tactile hallucinations

Explanation of other options:

Visual hallucinations (Option A): Visual hallucinations are very common in delirium tremens. They are typically lilliputian hallucinations.

Tactile hallucinations (Option B): Tactile hallucinations are less common in DT compared to visual hallucinations. An individual may experience formication, a classic tactile hallucination seen in delirium tremens.

Autonomic disturbances (Option C): DTs involve severe autonomic hyperactivity, including tremors, tachycardia, hypertension, fever, and diaphoresis.

Alcohol dependence:

Alcohol dependence is divided into 2 subtypes based primarily on phenomenological characteristics:

A 30-year-old woman presents with anxiety attacks occurring mid to late afternoon for one month. She complains of restlessness, nervousness, flushing, sweating, and agitation. She reported having increased her coffee intake to 6-7 cups per day in the afternoon due to work stress. What is the minimum daily caffeine intake likely to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Caffeine intoxication:

  • Caffeine is the most widely consumed psychoactive substance.
  • DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for caffeine intoxication include the recent consumption of caffeine, usually over 250 mg.
  • Single low to moderate doses of caffeine (i.e., 20 to 200 mg) can produce a profile of subjective effects in humans that is generally identified as pleasurable. (Option A ruled out)
  • Thus, studies have shown that such doses of caffeine result in increased ratings on measures such as well-being, energy, concentration and motivation to work.
  • In addition, these doses of caffeine produce decreases in ratings of feeling sleepy or tired.
  • Doses of caffeine in the range of 300 to 800 mg (the equivalent of several cups of brewed coffee ingested at once) produce effects that are often rated as being unpleasant, such as anxiety and nervousness.
  • Consumption of more than 1 g of caffeine can produce: (Option C ruled out)
    • Rambling speech
    • Confused thinking
    • Cardiac arrhythmias
    • Inexhaustibleness
    • Marked agitation
    • Tinnitus
    • Mild visual hallucinations (light flashes)
  • Consumption of more than 10 g of caffeine can cause generalised tonic-clonic seizures, respiratory failure and death. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 22-year-old unemployed male is brought to the ED by friends after an alleged history of smoking cannabis "joints" at a party. He complains of tripling the size of his friend's face and the room becoming distorted and changing in colour and proportion. He is anxious, and examination showed bilateral conjunctival injection and increased HR. All of the following are true about such an intoxicated state except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The symptoms are suggestive of Cannabis intoxication, and Cannabis is associated only with psychological dependence and not physical dependence.

  • Cannabis is the most commonly illegally used drug in India and the world, known by street names - joint, marijuana, grass, pot, and weed.
  • The active ingredient of Cannabis is delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol, which is responsible for its addictive nature. (Option C)
  • The cannabinoid receptor is found in highest concentrations in the basal ganglia, the hippocampus, and the cerebellum, with lower concentrations in the cerebral cortex.
  • The most common route of administration is by smoking.
  • Only psychological dependence is seen with cannabis use; physical withdrawal symptoms are not seen. (Option B)
  • When cannabis is smoked, the euphoric effects appear within minutes, peak in about 30 minutes and last 2 to 4 hours.

Cannabis intoxication:

  • Symptoms of cannabis intoxication include:
    • Voracious appetite
    • Dry mouth
    • Reddening of the conjunctiva
    • Euphoria
    • Synaesthesia (crossing of senses).
    • An unpleasant experience (like fear, extreme anxiety) is called a Bad Trip.
  • Cannabis intoxication commonly heightens user's sensitivities to external stimuli, reveals new details, makes colours seem brighter and richer, and subjectively slows the appreciation of time. Thus, in high doses, users may experience depersonalization and derealization. (Option B)

Cannabis related disorders

  • Hemp insanity refers to cannabis induced psychosis associated with delusions and hallucinations.
  • Cannabis and LSD are known to cause the Flashback phenomenon due to their high fat solubility. It refers to the recurrence of cannabis use experience in the absence of current cannabis use.
  • Running amok: A sudden, uncontrolled, violent outburst seen with cannabis use, resulting in hurting or killing someone. (Option D)

Key Takeaways:

Cannabis and LSD:

  • No physical dependence
  • Flashback phenomenon
  • High fat solubility

questions.text: In a debate about the legalisation of cannabis, the defenders could defend against the topic, citing risk for all of the following complications with long-term use of cannabis, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Intraparenchymal haemorrhage is not characteristic of cannabis use. Such cerebrovascular events are more common long-term adverse effects of stimulant drugs like amphetamine, cocaine.

Effects of cannabis use:

  • The most common physical effects of cannabis are red eyes and mild tachycardia.
  • Increased appetite, often referred to as "the munchies", and dry mouth are common effects of cannabis intoxication.
  • The delirium associated with cannabis intoxication is characterised by marked impairment in cognition and performance tasks.
  • Long-term heavy cannabis use is associated with depressive symptoms, amotivational syndrome, cannabis cannabis-induced psychotic disorder (hemp sanity).

Complications associated with long-term cannabis use:

  • Cerebral atrophy
  • Seizure susceptibility
  • Chromosomal damage, birth defects
  • Impaired immune reactivity
  • Alterations in testosterone concentrations and dysregulation of menstrual cycles.

Running amok is a serious complication associated with long-term cannabis use in which an individual develops rage following cannabis use and may hurt or even kill someone.

Explanation of other options:

Amotivational Syndrome (Option A): Amotivational syndrome has been associated with long-term heavy cannabis use and has been characterised by a person's unwillingness to persist in a task-be it at school, at work, or in any setting that requires prolonged attention or tenacity. Persons are described as becoming apathetic and anergic, usually gaining weight, and appearing slothful.

Cognitive impairment (Option C): Long-term use of cannabis may produce subtle forms of cognitive impairment in the higher cognitive functions of memory, attention, organisation and the integration of complex information.

Hemp insanity (Option D): The psychotic episodes associated with long-term heavy cannabis use are referred to as "hemp insanity". It is associated with delusions and hallucinations.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student presents with complaints of numerous white pinpoint spots scattered across both the central and peripheral visual fields. He also reports visual trailing, where moving objects appear to leave behind a trail as they pass through his visual field. These visual disturbances have developed gradually over the past 3 months following recreational drug use. Examinations by both an ophthalmologist and a neurologist revealed no abnormalities. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for this visual syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The symptoms described above, as white pinpoint spots and visual trailing with a normal neurological and ophthalmological examination, are highly suggestive of hallucinogen persisting perception disorder.

  • Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) is a classic synthetic hallucinogen. Also known as "blotter acid".
  • Hallucinogen intoxication is characterised by:
    • Pupillary dilation
    • Tachycardia
    • Sweating
    • Palpitations
    • Blurring of vision
    • Tremors
    • Incoordination

Hallucinogen persisting perception disorder:

  • Also known as flashbacks are spontaneous, transitory recurrences of the hallucinogen-induced experience.
  • Most flashbacks are episodes of:
    • Visual distortion
    • Geometric hallucinations
    • Hallucinations of sounds or voices
    • False perceptions of movement in peripheral fields
    • Flashes of colour
    • Trails of images from moving objects
    • Positive afterimages and halos
    • Macropsia
    • Micropsia
    • Time expansion
    • Physical symptoms
    • Relieved intense emotion.
  • The episodes usually last a few seconds to a few minutes, but sometimes last longer.
  • Flashbacks are commonly seen with Lysergic acid diethylamide and Cannabis.

Explanation of other options:

Methamphetamine (Option B): Methamphetamine is generally misused to increase performance and induce a euphoric feeling. Long-term use can result in amphetamine psychotic disorder, the hallmark of which is paranoid delusions and auditory hallucinations.

Cocaine (Option C): Cocaine intoxication is characterised by euphoria, tachycardia, HTN, pupillary dilation, and sweating. Moderate to high doses can cause paranoid ideations, auditory hallucinations, and visual illusions. Magnan phenomenon is a classical example of cocaine-induced formication - a tactile hallucination that may lead users to scratch or injure themselves in attempts to remove imaginary insects. Also called the cocaine bug.

Opium (Option D): Opium includes psychoactive substances like Morphine, Codeine, and Heroin. They produce euphoria, a feeling of warmth, heaviness extremities, and facial flushing.

Hallucinogen intoxication:

  • Intoxication with hallucinogens like LSD is characterised by maladaptive behavioural and perceptual changes and by certain physiological signs.
  • Typical symptoms include depersonalisation, derealisation, synaesthesia, illusion, hallucinations, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • The sympathomimetic effects of LSD include tremors, tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia, sweating, blurring of vision, and mydriasis.
  • Death caused by cardiac or cerebrovascular pathology related to hypertension, hyperthermia, can occur with hallucinogenic use.
  • Bad trip and Flashback phenomenon are potential adverse effects associated with long-term LSD use.
  • Flashbacks are spontaneous, transitory recurrences of the substance-induced experience, while bad trip is an unpleasant experience of fear or anxiety.

Explanation of other options:

questions.text: After taking excessive IV shots of some substance, a 19-year-old habitual IV drug abuser presented in a comatose state with pinpoint pupils, slurred speech, shallow breathing and confused behaviour. What would be the next best step in his management?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The above case scenario represents opioid intoxication (probably heroin-suggestive by pinpoint pupils, slurred speech, respiratory depression, decreased attention and concentration).
  • The first task in overdose treatment is to ensure an adequate airway.
  • Tracheopharyngeal secretions should be aspirated; an airway may be inserted.
  • The patient should be ventilated mechanically until naloxone, a specific opioid antagonist, can be given. (Option B)
  • Naloxone is administered intravenously at a slow rate initially, about 0.8 mg per 70 kg of body weight.

Explanation of other options:

Perform a drug screening test (Option C): Since the clinical presentation suggests opioid overdose, performing a drug screening test would delay the life-saving treatment.

Administer buprenorphine (Option D): Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used for opioid dependence and not acute opioid overdose reversal.

questions.text: A 26-year-old manual labourer presents with severe myalgias, palpitations, diaphoresis, lacrimation, yawning, diarrhoea, vomiting, and insomnia for 6 days. He reports chronic use of 'Afim' for 8 years to manage work-related fatigue, but stopped abruptly due to social pressure before his marriage. Match the following medications to their most appropriate role in managing his condition:
questions.solution:
Afim is the street name for Opium, and his current symptoms are most consistent with Opioid Withdrawal.

  • Clonidine(A-4) is used during opioid detoxification to reduce symptoms due to sympathetic overactivity, like sweating, palpitations, etc.
  • Buprenorphine(B-3) is an opioid partial agonist that can be used as a substitute for opioids so that withdrawal symptoms are not precipitated.
  • Lorazepam(C-2) can be used for insomnia seen in opioid withdrawal.
  • Naltrexone(D-1) is a competitive opioid antagonist. It induces withdrawal effects in people using opioids or full opioid agonists.
  • Tramadol(E-5) is an opioid agonist that is helpful in analgesia, for treating muscle aches that occur in opioid withdrawal.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student, previously well functioning, started using large amounts of methamphetamine before final exams as he felt unprepared for the exams. Soon, he developed false beliefs of being followed by police and/or a detective at the request of his parents. Also claims that his roommate was reporting to the detective regarding his social life and study habits. Which of the following statements is appropriate regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The above case scenario is suggestive of stimulant-induced psychotic disorder.

Cocaine, amphetamine are among the commonly abused stimulants.

Stimulant-Induced Psychotic Disorder:

  • The hallmark of stimulant-induced psychotic disorder is the presence of paranoid delusions and hallucinations.
  • Auditory hallucinations are also common, but visual and tactile hallucinations are less common than paranoid delusions. The sensation of bugs crawling beneath the skin (formication) - cocaine bugs has been associated with cocaine use.
  • Cocaine-induced psychotic disorders are most common with intravenous use and crack use, and the psychotic symptoms are more common in men than in women.
  • The treatment of choice for stimulant-induced psychotic disorder is the short-term use of an antipsychotic medication such as haloperidol (Haldol).

Explanation of other options:

Methamphetamine has serotonergic action, which produces such symptoms (Option A): Methamphetamine produces its primary effects by causing the release of catecholamines, particularly dopamine, from presynaptic terminals.

Treatment with Fluoxetine would help manage his symptoms(Option C): Fluoxetine is an SSRI and cannot be used for dopamine-related psychosis.

questions.text: Substances of abuse that are structural or functional analogues of a controlled substance that have been designed to mimic the pharmacological effects of the original drug, while avoiding classification as illegal and/or detection in standard drug tests are termed as:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • A designer drug is a structural or functional analogue of a controlled substance that has been designed to mimic the pharmacological effects of the original drug, while avoiding classification as illegal and/or detection in standard drug tests.
  • Designer drugs include psychoactive substances that have been designated by the European Union as new psychoactive substances(NPS), as well as analogues of performance-enhancing drugs such as designer steroids.
  • Examples of designer drugs: MDMA, mephedrone

Explanation of other options:

Club drugs (Option A): These are a group of substances associated with dance clubs, bars and all-night dance parties (raves). Examples - LSD, Alpha-hydroxybutyrate (GHB), Ketamine, Methamphetamine, MDMA (Ecstasy), Rohypnol or "roofies" (flunitrazepam). These substances are not all in the same drug class, and they do not produce the same physical or subjective effects. GHB and Rohypnol have been called date rape drugs because they produce the disorienting and sedative effects.

Performance enhancing drugs, Doping drugs (Option C, D): Anabolic androgenic steroids and stimulants come under this group, which are often misused among bodybuilders, athletes, and students to increase one's performance and endurance

questions.text: Drug-facilitated rape is a type of acquaintance sexual assault done by allegedly placing some drugs in the beverage of the victim surreptitiously. The sexual encounter is not remembered by the victim due to anterograde amnesia. Which drug out of the following is a 'date rape drug':
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Gamma-Hydroxy-Butyrate, ketamine, and Rohypnol or "roofies"(Flunitrazepam) have been called 'date rape drugs' because they produce disorienting and sedating effects and often users cannot recall what occurred during all or part of an episode under the influence of the drug.
  • Hence, it is alleged that these drugs might be surreptitiously placed in a beverage, or a person might be convinced to take the drug and then not recall clearly what occurred after ingestion.
  • They belong to the broad category of club drugs.

Explanation of other options:

Nitrate inhaler (Option A): Nitrite inhalants are used by persons seeking the associated mild euphoria, altered sense of time, feeling of fullness in the head, and, possibly, increased sexual feelings. Example: Amyl nitrate (poppers).

Cocaine (Option B): Cocaine is a stimulant that, when used, produces effects of elation, euphoria, heightened self-esteem, and perceived improvement on mental and physical tasks.

Heroin (Option D): Heroin is a synthetic opioid drug, which, when used initially, produces a sense of euphoria followed by sedation (nodding off). But is not a date rape drug.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man, who smoked 35-40 cigarettes per day for the last 20 years, was referred for smoking cessation by his physician after he developed a persistent cough and breathlessness on exertion. Rearrange the steps below in his management in order:
1 - Start nicotine replacement therapy
2 - If motivated enough, set a quit date
3 - Start the anti-craving agent Bupropion around 15 days before the quit date
4 - Enhance the motivation of the patient for quitting smoking
5 - Prevent relapse by identifying high-risk situations and eliminating cues for smoking in the environment.
questions.solution:
The above figure depicts the stages of the change model.

  • Any person having any substance use disorder, in this case, tobacco use disorder, needs to be motivated internally or externally for smoking cessation and thus brought into the contemplation stage.
  • When the person is motivated enough (Preparation stage), a quit date should be set.
  • After this, Nicotine replacement therapy can be started slowly and gradually to replace smoking with Nicotine gum or patches.
  • Bupropion, an anti-craving agent, should be started 10-15 days before the 'quit date'.
  • These steps are part of the action stage. After these, the patient should be maintained on the above-mentioned medications, and relapse should be prevented by identifying high-risk situations and eliminating cues for smoking in the environment (maintenance stage).
  • If relapse occurs, the stages should be repeated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a 2-year history of repeatedly borrowing money from colleagues due to financial losses in online gambling. He reports spending his salary on betting, lying to his wife about expenses, and feeling restless when attempting to stop. He has no history of substance use but reports insomnia and guilt. His wife mentions that he recently pawned her jewellery. Under which category of DSM-5 can this patient be classified?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

According to DSM-5, gambling disorder is classified under substance use disorders. In DSM-5, gambling disorder is included in the section on substance use and addictive disorders and is diagnosed as a non-substance-related disorder.

Gambling disorder:

Gambling disorder is characterised by persistent and recurrent maladaptive gambling that causes economic problems and significant disturbances in personal, social or occupational functioning.

Aspects of the maladaptive behaviour include :

  • A preoccupation with gambling
  • The need to gamble with increasing amounts of money to achieve the desired excitement
  • Repeated unsuccessful efforts to control, cut back or stop gambling
  • Gambling as a way to escape from problems
  • Gambling to recoup losses
  • Lying to conceal the extent of the involvement with gambling
  • The commission of illegal acts to finance gambling
  • Jeopardising or losing personal and vocational relationships because of gambling
  • A reliance on others for money to pay off debts

Complications associated with gambling disorder include alienation from family members and acquaintances, the loss of life accomplishments, suicide attempts, and association with fringe and illegal groups. An arrest for nonviolent crimes may lead to imprisonment.

Treatment:

  • Gamblers Anonymous is an effective treatment for gambling. It involves a method of inspirational group therapy that involves public confession, peer pressure and the presence of reformed gamblers.
  • Insight-oriented psychotherapy and cognitive behavioural therapy are also effective.
  • Pharmacological treatment with antidepressants, especially SSRIs and bupropion, mood stabilisers, antiepileptics such as topiramate, atypical antipsychotics, and opioid agents, naltrexone, has been found successful in managing gambling disorders.

DSM-5 classification recognises substance use disorders associated with alcohol, caffeine, cannabis, hallucinogen, opioid, benzodiazepines, stimulants, tobacco and certain other substances classified under other unknown substances like androgenic anabolic steroids, nitrate inhalants, etc.
